data.title: The semantics and syntax of horror films.
data.meta_description: Horror films of the past usually focused on a group of characters going to a isolated or forbidden area of the earth and encountering a external threat, usual a monster or a spirt. The film then ends…
data.text:
Semantics of horror include:

An isolated location

Low key lighting

Bad weather conditions

Blood, gore, and other gross out visuals that reflect our own bodies

Religious imagery

A cast of dim witted characters with only a few characters as the voices of reason

high pitched unsettling noises:

A paranoia inducing soundtrack

Leaving much of the visuals up to interpretation

a monster or an unknown entity

Confusing visuals

Close up shots to limit visibility

Syntactic of horror films:

Horror films of the past usually focused on a group of characters going to a isolated or forbidden area of the earth and encountering a external threat, usual a monster or a spirt. The film then ends with most if not all of the characters dead after a final attempt to kill the monster/spirt. An exploration of human helplessness against something they don’t fully understand.

However many horror films as of late are turning toward the mind for horror ideas, having a single protagonist face in issue in his/her mind that only they can deal with. And as such the horror comes from within instead of from outside a person. Even with this setup the film still manages to focus on an exploration of human helplessness against something they don’t fully understand (which in this case is themselves).
